awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Deep Learning and Software Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a workshop to explore synergies between Deep Learning and Software Engineering. The goal is to accelerate research that uses Deep Learning in research and practice to improve techniques and tools for Software Engineering through the power of Deep Learning. Conversely, deep-learning based systems, which are emerging in many application domains, need new Software Engineering approaches render them correct, reliable and comprehensible. The workshop will bring together researchers and practitioners in both fields to discuss research priorities community resources needed to accelerate research in the intersection of Deep Learning and Software Engineering. 

Deep Learning represents a fundamental shift in the manner by which machines learn patterns from data by automatically extracting salient features for a given computational task, as opposed to relying upon human intuition. Deep Learning approaches are characterized by architectures comprised of several layers that perform mathematical transformations, according to sets of learnable parameters, on data passing through them.  These computational layers and parameters form models that can be trained for specific tasks, such as image classification, by updating the parameters according to a model?s performance on a labeled set of training data. Given the immense amount of data in software repositories that can serve as training data, deep learning techniques have ushered in advancements across a range of tasks in software engineering research including automatic software repair, code suggestion, defect prediction, malware detection, feature location, and many others. The workshop will review the state of the research and practice and give guidance to the community about opportunities and challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The goal of thie proposal was to organize workshop(s) to bring together an international group of researchers and practitioners who work at the intersection of software engineering and deep learning (and current days LLM) for an intensive period of discussion. There are clear instances where SE researchers could benefit from collaboration with DL researchers and vice versa. Thus, the overarching theme of this discussion will be related to the synergies that exist between research on SE and DL, and the most promising avenues of future work that should be prioritized to advance both fields.

Over the last five years we organized two major workshops:

  1. DLSE, co-located with ASE 2019. The details of the workshop can be found here: https://dlse-workshop.gitlab.io/
  2. MAPS, co-located with FSE 2023. The details of the workshop can be found here: https://mapsworkshop.github.io/

As per the goals of the workshop, we intend the workshop report to be an open living document that outlines promising future work that sits at the intersection of Deep Learning and Software Engineering. MAPS 2023 involved several discussions of new ideas from the students. We hope students and researchers will be motivated by the workshop outcome, and we will integrate it into the course content. We made the outcome of the workshop available here: https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.08525 and https://mapsworkshop.github.io/papers. 

Deep learning, particularly through large language models (LLMs), has had a profound impact on software engineering, fundamentally altering the way developers write, debug, and optimize code. The introduction of AI-powered coding assistants, such as GitHub Copilot, Amazon Q, and Cursor AI, has revolutionized the software development process by automating repetitive coding tasks, suggesting context-aware code completions, and even generating entire functions or modules based on natural language prompts. These advancements stem from foundational research and discussions in the field, many of which were initially explored in workshops and academic forums focused on the intersection of AI and software engineering.

Moreover, the influence of AI in software engineering extends beyond industry applications; it has significantly shaped academic research in the field. The majority of contemporary studies now fall under the domain of AI for Software Engineering (AI4SE), where researchers explore how machine learning and AI techniques can enhance various aspects of software development, including automated testing, bug detection, code synthesis, software maintenance, and security. This shift in focus has led to the publication of numerous papers investigating novel AI-driven methodologies to improve software engineering practices. As a result, both academia and industry are experiencing a paradigm shift where AI is no longer just an auxiliary tool but a fundamental component of modern software development.

 


Last Modified: 02/26/2025
Modified by: Baishakhi Ray
